Algorithmically Effective Differentially Private Synthetic Data

Yiyun He Department of Mathematics, University of California Irvine, Irvine, CA 92697 yiyunh4@uci.edu ,Â  Roman Vershynin Department of Mathematics, University of California Irvine, Irvine, CA 92697 rvershyn@uci.edu Â andÂ  Yizhe Zhu Department of Mathematics, University of California Irvine, Irvine, CA 92697 yizhe.zhu@uci.edu
Abstract.

We present a highly effective algorithmic approach for generating Îµğœ€\varepsilon-differentially private synthetic data in a bounded metric space with near-optimal utility guarantees under the 1-Wasserstein distance. In particular, for a dataset ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} in the hypercube [0,1]dsuperscript01ğ‘‘[0,1]^{d}, our algorithm generates synthetic dataset ğ’´ğ’´\mathcal{Y} such that the expected 1-Wasserstein distance between the empirical measure of ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} and ğ’´ğ’´\mathcal{Y} is Oâ€‹((Îµâ€‹n)âˆ’1/d)ğ‘‚superscriptğœ€ğ‘›1ğ‘‘O((\varepsilon n)^{-1/d}) for dâ‰¥2ğ‘‘2d\geq 2, and is Oâ€‹(log2â¡(Îµâ€‹n)â€‹(Îµâ€‹n)âˆ’1)ğ‘‚superscript2ğœ€ğ‘›superscriptğœ€ğ‘›1O(\log^{2}(\varepsilon n)(\varepsilon n)^{-1}) for d=1ğ‘‘1d=1. The accuracy guarantee is optimal up to a constant factor for dâ‰¥2ğ‘‘2d\geq 2, and up to a logarithmic factor for d=1ğ‘‘1d=1. Our algorithm has a fast running time of Oâ€‹(Îµâ€‹dâ€‹n)ğ‘‚ğœ€ğ‘‘ğ‘›O(\varepsilon dn) for all dâ‰¥1ğ‘‘1d\geq 1 and demonstrates improved accuracy compared to the method in [12] for dâ‰¥2ğ‘‘2d\geq 2.

1. Introduction

Differential privacy has become the benchmark for privacy protection in scenarios where vast amounts of data need to be analyzed. The aim of differential privacy is to prevent the disclosure of information about individual participants in the dataset. In simple terms, an algorithm that has a randomized output and produces similar results when given two adjacent datasets is considered to be differentially private. This method of privacy protection is increasingly being adopted and implemented in various fields, including the 2020 US Census [2, 29, 28] and numerous machine learning tasks [24].

A wide range of data computations can be performed in a differentially private manner, including regression [17], clustering [37], parameter estimation [21], stochastic gradient descent [36], and deep learning [1]. However, many existing works on differential privacy focus on designing algorithms for specific tasks and are restricted to queries that are predefined before use. This requires expert knowledge and often involves modifying existing algorithms.

One promising solution to this challenge is to generate a synthetic dataset similar to the original dataset with guaranteed differential privacy [27, 8, 31, 7, 10, 11, 12]. As any downstream tasks are based on the synthetic dataset, they can be performed without incurring additional privacy costs.

1.1. Private synthetic data

Mathematically, the problem of generating private synthetic data can be defined as follows. Let (Î©,Ï)Î©ğœŒ(\Omega,\rho) be a metric space. Consider a dataset ğ’³=(X1,â€¦,Xn)âˆˆÎ©nğ’³subscriptğ‘‹1â€¦subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›superscriptÎ©ğ‘›\mathcal{X}=(X_{1},\dots,X_{n})\in\Omega^{n}. Our goal is to construct an efficient randomized algorithm that outputs differentially private synthetic data ğ’´=(Y1,â€¦,Ym)âˆˆÎ©mğ’´subscriptğ‘Œ1â€¦subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsuperscriptÎ©ğ‘š\mathcal{Y}=(Y_{1},\dots,Y_{m})\in\Omega^{m} such that the two empirical measures

Î¼ğ’³=1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nÎ´XiandÎ¼ğ’´=1mâ€‹âˆ‘i=1mÎ´Yiformulae-sequencesubscriptğœ‡ğ’³1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ›¿subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–andsubscriptğœ‡ğ’´1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsubscriptğ›¿subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–\mu_{\mathcal{X}}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\delta_{X_{i}}\quad\text{and}\quad\mu_{\mathcal{Y}}=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\delta_{Y_{i}}

are close to each other. We measure the utility of the output by ğ”¼â¡W1â€‹(Î¼ğ’³,Î¼ğ’´)ğ”¼subscriptğ‘Š1subscriptğœ‡ğ’³subscriptğœ‡ğ’´\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{Y}}), where W1â€‹(Î¼ğ’³,Î¼ğ’´)subscriptğ‘Š1subscriptğœ‡ğ’³subscriptğœ‡ğ’´W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{Y}}) is the 1-Wasserstein distance, and the expectation is taken over the randomness of the algorithm. The Kantorovich-Rubinstein duality (see, e.g., [47]) gives an equivalent representation of the 1-Wasserstein distance between two measures Î½ğ’³subscriptğœˆğ’³\nu_{\mathcal{X}} and Î¼ğ’´subscriptğœ‡ğ’´\mu_{\mathcal{Y}}:

W1â€‹(Î¼ğ’³,Î¼ğ’´)=supLipâ€‹(f)â‰¤1(âˆ«fâ€‹dÎ¼ğ’³âˆ’âˆ«fâ€‹dÎ¼ğ’´),subscriptğ‘Š1subscriptğœ‡ğ’³subscriptğœ‡ğ’´subscriptsupremumLipğ‘“1ğ‘“differential-dsubscriptğœ‡ğ’³ğ‘“differential-dsubscriptğœ‡ğ’´W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{Y}})=\sup_{{\mathrm{Lip}(f)}\leq 1}\left(\int f\mathrm{d}\mu_{\mathcal{X}}-\int f\mathrm{d}\mu_{\mathcal{Y}}\right), (1.1)

where the supremum is taken over the set of all 111-Lipschitz functions on Î©Î©\Omega. Since many machine learning algorithms are Lipschitz [48, 32, 15, 35], EquationÂ (1.1) provides a uniform accuracy guarantee for a wide range of machine learning tasks performed on synthetic datasets whose empirical measure is close to Î¼ğ’³subscriptğœ‡ğ’³\mu_{\mathcal{X}} in the 1-Wasserstein distance.

1.2. Main results

The most straightforward way to construct differentially private synthetic data is to add independent noise to the location of each data point. However, this method can result in a significant loss of data utility as the amount of noise needed for privacy protection may be too large [20]. Another direct approach could be to add noise to the density function of the empirical measure of ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}, by dividing Î©Î©\Omega into small subregions and perturbing the true counts in each subregion. However, Laplacian noise may perturb the count in a certain subregion to negative, causing the output to become a signed measure. To address this issue, we introduce an algorithmically effective method called the Private Measure Mechanism.

Private Measure Mechanism (PMM)

PMM makes the count zero if the noisy count in a subregion is negative. Instead of a single partition of Î©Î©\Omega, we consider a collection of binary hierarchical partitions on Î©Î©\Omega and add inhomogeneous noise to each level of the partition. However, the counts of two subregions do not always add up to the count of the region at a higher level. We develop an algorithm that enforces the consistency of counts in regions at different levels. PMM has Oâ€‹(Îµâ€‹dâ€‹n)ğ‘‚ğœ€ğ‘‘ğ‘›O(\varepsilon dn) running time while the running time of the approach in [12] is polynomial in nğ‘›n.

The accuracy analysis of PMM uses the hierarchical partitions to estimate the 1-Wasserstein distance in terms of the multi-scale geometry of Î©Î©\Omega and the noise magnitude in each level of the partition. In particular, when Î©=[0,1]dÎ©superscript01ğ‘‘\Omega=[0,1]^{d}, by optimizing the choice of the hierarchical partitions and noise magnitude, PMM achieves better accuracy compared to [12] for dâ‰¥2ğ‘‘2d\geq 2. The accuracy is optimal rate up to a constant factor for dâ‰¥2ğ‘‘2d\geq 2, and up to a logarithmic factor for d=1ğ‘‘1d=1. We state it in the next theorem.

The hierarchical partitions appeared in many previous works on the approximation of distributions under Wasserstein distances in a non-private setting, including [4, 18, 50]. In the differential privacy literature, the hierarchical partitions are also closely related to the binary tree mechanism [22, 16] for differential privacy under continual observation. However, the accuracy analysis of the two mechanisms is significantly different. In addition, the TopDown algorithm in the 2020 census [3] also has a similar hierarchical structure and enforces consistency, but the accuracy analysis of the algorithm is not provided in [3].

Theorem 1.1 (PMM for data in a hypercube).

Let Î©=[0,1]dÎ©superscript01ğ‘‘\Omega=[0,1]^{d} equipped with the â„“âˆsuperscriptâ„“\ell^{\infty} metric. PMM outputs an Îµğœ€\varepsilon-differentially private synthetic dataset ğ’´ğ’´\mathcal{Y} in time Oâ€‹(Îµâ€‹dâ€‹n)ğ‘‚ğœ€ğ‘‘ğ‘›O(\varepsilon dn) such that

ğ”¼W1(Î¼ğ’³,Î¼ğ’´)â‰¤{Câ€‹log2â¡(Îµâ€‹n)â€‹(Îµâ€‹n)âˆ’1Â ifÂ â€‹d=1,Câ€‹(Îµâ€‹n)âˆ’1dÂ ifÂ â€‹dâ‰¥2.\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{Y}})\leq\left\{\begin{aligned} &C\log^{2}(\varepsilon n)(\varepsilon n)^{-1}&\quad\textrm{ if }d=1,\\ &C{(\varepsilon n)^{-\frac{1}{d}}}&\quad\textrm{ if }d\geq 2.\end{aligned}\right.

Private Signed Measure Mechanism (PSMM)

In addition to PMM, we introduce an alternative method, the Private Signed Measure Mechanism, that achieves optimal accuracy rate on [0,1]dsuperscript01ğ‘‘[0,1]^{d} when dâ‰¥3ğ‘‘3d\geq 3 in polyâ€‹(n)polyğ‘›\text{poly}(n) time. The analysis of PSMM is not restricted to 1-Wasserstein distance, and it can be generalized to provide a uniform utility guarantee of other function classes.

We first partition the domain Î©Î©\Omega into mğ‘šm subregions Î©1,â€¦,Î©msubscriptÎ©1â€¦subscriptÎ©ğ‘š\Omega_{1},\dots,\Omega_{m}. Perturbing the counts in each subregion with i.i.d. integer Laplacian noise gives an unbiased approximation of Î¼ğ’´subscriptğœ‡ğ’´\mu_{\mathcal{Y}} with a signed measure Î½ğœˆ\nu. Then we find the closest probability measure Î½^^ğœˆ\hat{\nu} under the bounded Lipschitz distance by solving a linear programming problem.

In the proof of accuracy for PSMM, one ingredient is to estimate the Laplacian complexity of the Lipschitz function class on Î©Î©\Omega and connect it to the 1-Wasserstein distance. This type of argument is similar in spirit to the optimal matching problem for two sets of random points in a metric space [38, 39, 9]. When Î©=[0,1]dÎ©superscript01ğ‘‘\Omega=[0,1]^{d}, PSMM achieves the optimal accuracy rate Oâ€‹((Îµâ€‹n)âˆ’1/d)ğ‘‚superscriptğœ€ğ‘›1ğ‘‘O((\varepsilon n)^{-1/d}) for dâ‰¥3ğ‘‘3d\geq 3. For d=2ğ‘‘2d=2, PSMM achieves a near-optimal accuracy Oâ€‹(logâ¡(Îµâ€‹n)â€‹(Îµâ€‹n)âˆ’1/2)ğ‘‚ğœ€ğ‘›superscriptğœ€ğ‘›12O(\log(\varepsilon n)(\varepsilon n)^{-1/2}). For d=1ğ‘‘1d=1, the accuracy becomes Oâ€‹((Îµâ€‹n)âˆ’1/2)ğ‘‚superscriptğœ€ğ‘›12O((\varepsilon n)^{-1/2}).

For the case when d=2ğ‘‘2d=2, we believe that the bound in Corollary 3.7 could be improved to Câ€‹logâ¡(Îµâ€‹n)/Îµâ€‹nğ¶ğœ€ğ‘›ğœ€ğ‘›C\sqrt{\log(\varepsilon n)}/\sqrt{\varepsilon n} by replacing Dudleyâ€™s chaining bound in Proposition 3.2 with the generic chaining bound in [39, 19] involving the Î³1subscriptğ›¾1\gamma_{1} and Î³2subscriptğ›¾2\gamma_{2} functionals on Î©Î©\Omega. We will not pursue this direction in this paper.

Comparison to previous results

[42] proved that it is NP-hard to generate private synthetic data on the Boolean cube which approximately preserves all two-dimensional marginals, assuming the existence of one-way functions. There exists a substantial body of work for differentially private synthetic data with guarantees limited to accuracy bounds for a finite set of specified queries [5, 40, 23, 43, 33, 46, 12, 13, 14].

[49] considered differentially private synthetic data in [0,1]dsuperscript01ğ‘‘[0,1]^{d} with guarantees for any smooth queries with bounded partial derivatives of order Kğ¾K, and achieved an accuracy of Oâ€‹(Îµâˆ’1â€‹nâˆ’K2â€‹d+K)ğ‘‚superscriptğœ€1superscriptğ‘›ğ¾2ğ‘‘ğ¾O(\varepsilon^{-1}n^{-\frac{K}{2d+K}}). Recently, [12] introduced a method based on superregular random walks to generate differentially private synthetic data with near-optimal guarantees in general compact metric spaces. In particular, when the dataset is in [0,1]dsuperscript01ğ‘‘[0,1]^{d}, they obtain ğ”¼â¡W1â€‹(Î¼ğ’³,Î¼ğ’´)â‰¤Câ€‹log32â€‹dâ¡(Îµâ€‹n)â€‹(Îµâ€‹n)âˆ’1dğ”¼subscriptğ‘Š1subscriptğœ‡ğ’³subscriptğœ‡ğ’´ğ¶superscript32ğ‘‘ğœ€ğ‘›superscriptğœ€ğ‘›1ğ‘‘\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{Y}})\leq C\log^{\frac{3}{2d}}(\varepsilon n)(\varepsilon n)^{-\frac{1}{d}}. A corresponding lower bound of order nâˆ’1/dsuperscriptğ‘›1ğ‘‘n^{-1/d} was also proved in [12, Corollary 9.3]. PMM matches the lower bound up to a constant factor for dâ‰¥2ğ‘‘2d\geq 2, and up to a logarithmic factor for d=1ğ‘‘1d=1.

In terms of computational efficiency, PMM runs in time Oâ€‹(Îµâ€‹dâ€‹n)ğ‘‚ğœ€ğ‘‘ğ‘›O(\varepsilon dn). This is more efficient compared to the algorithm in [12].

Organization of the paper

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In SectionÂ 2, we introduce some background on differential privacy and distances between measures. We will first introduce and analyze the easier and more direct method PSMM before our main result. In SectionÂ 3, we describe PSMM in detail and prove its privacy and accuracy for data in a bounded metric space, and detailed results are provided for the case for the hypercube. In SectionÂ 4, we introduce PMM and analyze its privacy and accuracy. Optimizing the choices of noise parameters, we obtain the optimal accuracy on the hypercube with Oâ€‹(Îµâ€‹dâ€‹n)ğ‘‚ğœ€ğ‘‘ğ‘›O(\varepsilon dn) running time, which proves TheoremÂ 1.1.

Additional proofs are included in AppendixÂ A. We use a variant of Laplacian distribution, called discrete Laplacian distribution, in PMM and PSMM. The definition and properties of discrete Laplacian distribution are included in Appendix B.

2. Preliminaries

Differential Privacy

We use the following definition from [24]. A randomized algorithm â„³â„³\mathcal{M} provides Îµğœ€\varepsilon-differential privacy if for any input data D,Dâ€²ğ·superscriptğ·â€²D,D^{\prime} that differs on only one element (or Dğ·D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime} are adjacent data sets) and for any measurable set SâŠ†rangeâ€‹(â„³)ğ‘†rangeâ„³S\subseteq\mathrm{range}(\mathcal{M}), there is

â„™â€‹{â„³â€‹(D)âˆˆSâ€‹}â„™â€‹{â„³â€‹(Dâ€²)âˆˆSâ€‹}â‰¤eÎµ.â„™â„³ğ·ğ‘†â„™â„³superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘†superscriptğ‘’ğœ€\frac{\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{M}(D)\in S\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}{\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})\in S\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}\leq e^{\varepsilon}.

Here the probability is taken from the probability space of the randomness of â„³â„³\mathcal{M}.

where Î³â€‹(Î¼,Î½)ğ›¾ğœ‡ğœˆ\gamma(\mu,\nu) is the set of all couplings of Î¼ğœ‡\mu and Î½ğœˆ\nu.

3. Private signed measure mechanism (PSMM)

We will first introduce PSMM, which is an easier and more intuitive approach. The procedure of PSMM is formally described in AlgorithmÂ 1. Note that in the output step of AlgorithmÂ 1, the size of the synthetic data mâ€²superscriptğ‘šâ€²m^{\prime} depends on the rational approximation of the density function of Î½^^ğœˆ\hat{\nu}, and we discuss the details here. Let v^1,â€¦,v^msubscript^ğ‘£1â€¦subscript^ğ‘£ğ‘š\hat{v}_{1},\dots,\hat{v}_{m} be the weight of the probability measure Î½^^ğœˆ\hat{\nu} on y1,â€¦,ymsubscriptğ‘¦1â€¦subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘šy_{1},\dots,y_{m}, respectively. We can choose rational numbers r1,â€¦,rmsubscriptğ‘Ÿ1â€¦subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šr_{1},\dots,r_{m} such that maxiâˆˆ[m]â¡|riâˆ’Î½^i|subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–subscript^ğœˆğ‘–\max_{i\in[m]}|r_{i}-\hat{\nu}_{i}| is arbitrarily small. Let mâ€²superscriptğ‘šâ€²m^{\prime} be the least common multiple of the denominators of r1,â€¦,rmsubscriptğ‘Ÿ1â€¦subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šr_{1},\dots,r_{m}, then we output the synthetic dataset ğ’´^^ğ’´\hat{\mathcal{Y}} containing mâ€²â€‹risuperscriptğ‘šâ€²subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–m^{\prime}r_{i} copies of yisubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–y_{i} for i=1,â€¦,mğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘ši=1,\dots,m.

Before analyzing the privacy and accuracy of PSMM, we introduce a useful complexity measure of a given function class, which quantifies the influence of the Laplacian noise on the function class.

3.1. Laplacian complexity

Given the Kantorovich-Rubinstein duality (1.1), to control the W1subscriptğ‘Š1W_{1}-distance between the original measure and the private measure, we need to describe how Lipschitz functions behave under Laplacian noise. As an analog of the worst-case Rademacher complexity [6, 25], we consider the worst-case Laplacian complexity. Such a worst-case complexity measure appears since the original dataset is deterministic without any distribution assumption.

Definition 3.1 (Worst-case Laplacian complexity).

Let â„±â„±\mathcal{F} be a function class on a metric space Î©Î©\Omega. The worst-case Laplacian complexity of â„±â„±\mathcal{F} is defined by

Ln(â„±):=supX1,â€¦,XnâˆˆÎ©ğ”¼[supfâˆˆâ„±|1nâˆ‘i=1nÎ»if(Xi)|],\displaystyle L_{n}(\mathcal{F})\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}=\sup_{X_{1},\dots,X_{n}\in\Omega}\mathbb{E}\left[\sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}}\left|\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\lambda_{i}f(X_{i})\right|\right], (3.1)

where Î»1,â€¦,Î»nâˆ¼Lapâ¡(1)similar-tosubscriptğœ†1â€¦subscriptğœ†ğ‘›Lap1\lambda_{1},\dots,\lambda_{n}\sim\operatorname{Lap}(1) are i.i.d. random variables.

Since Laplacian random variables are sub-exponential but not sub-gaussian, its complexity measure is not equivalent to the Gaussian or Rademacher complexity, but it is related to the suprema of the mixed tail process [19] and the quadratic empirical process [34]. Our next proposition bounds Lnâ€‹(â„±)subscriptğ¿ğ‘›â„±L_{n}(\mathcal{F}) in terms of the covering numbers of â„±â„±\mathcal{F}. Its proof is a classical application of Dudleyâ€™s chaining method (see, e.g., [45]).

Proposition 3.2 (Bounding Laplacian complexity with Dudleyâ€™s entropy integral).

Suppose that (Î©,Ï)Î©ğœŒ(\Omega,\rho) is a metric space and â„±â„±\mathcal{F} is a set of functions on Î©Î©\Omega. Then

Ln(â„±)â‰¤CinfÎ±>0(2Î±+1nâˆ«Î±âˆlogğ’©(â„±,u,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ)du+1nâˆ«Î±âˆlogğ’©(â„±,u,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ)du)L_{n}(\mathcal{F})\leq C\inf_{\alpha>0}\left(2\alpha+\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\int_{\alpha}^{\infty}\sqrt{{\log\mathcal{N}(\mathcal{F},u,\|\cdot\|_{\infty})}}\mathrm{d}u+\frac{1}{{n}}\int_{\alpha}^{\infty}{\log\mathcal{N}(\mathcal{F},u,\|\cdot\|_{\infty})}\mathrm{d}u\right)

where ğ’©(â„±,u,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ)\mathcal{N}(\mathcal{F},u,\|\cdot\|_{\infty}) is the covering number of â„±â„±\mathcal{F} and C>0ğ¶0C>0 is an absolute constant.

In particular, we are interested in the case where â„±â„±\mathcal{F} is the class of all the bounded Lipschitz functions. One can find the result in [41] or more explicit bound in [26] that for the set â„±â„±\mathcal{F} of functions fğ‘“f with âˆ¥fâˆ¥Lipâ‰¤1subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘“Lip1\mathinner{\!\left\lVert f\right\rVert}_{\mathrm{Lip}}\leq 1, its covering number satisfies

When Î©=[0,1]dÎ©superscript01ğ‘‘\Omega=[0,1]^{d}, a better bound on the covering number for Lipschitz functions is available from [41, 48]:

ğ’©(â„±,u,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ)â‰¤(2âŒˆ2/uâŒ‰+1)2ğ’©([0,1]d,u/2,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ),\mathcal{N}(\mathcal{F},u,\|\cdot\|_{\infty})\leq\left(2\left\lceil{2}/u\right\rceil+1\right)2^{\mathcal{N}\left([0,1]^{d},u/2,\|\cdot\|_{\infty}\right)},

which implies the following corollary.

Corollary 3.3 (Laplacian complexity for Lipschitz functions on the hypercube).

Let Î©=[0,1]dÎ©superscript01ğ‘‘\Omega=[0,1]^{d} with the âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ\|\cdot\|_{\infty} metric, and â„±â„±\mathcal{F} be the set of all Lipschitz functions fğ‘“f on Î©Î©\Omega with âˆ¥fâˆ¥Lipâ‰¤1subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘“Lip1\mathinner{\!\left\lVert f\right\rVert}_{\mathrm{Lip}}\leq 1. We have

Discrete Laplacian complexity

Laplacian complexity can be useful for differential privacy algorithms based on the Laplacian mechanism [24]. However, since PSMM perturbs counts in each subregion, it is more convenient for us to add integer noise to the true counts. Instead, we will use the worst-case discrete Laplacian complexity defined below:

L~n(â„±):=supX1,â€¦,XnâˆˆÎ©ğ”¼[supfâˆˆâ„±|1nâˆ‘i=1nÎ»if(Xi)|],\displaystyle\widetilde{L}_{n}(\mathcal{F})\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}=\sup_{X_{1},\dots,X_{n}\in\Omega}\mathbb{E}\left[\sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}}\left|\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\lambda_{i}f(X_{i})\right|\right], (3.2)

where Î»1,â€¦,Î»nâˆ¼Lapâ„¤â¡(1)similar-tosubscriptğœ†1â€¦subscriptğœ†ğ‘›subscriptLapâ„¤1\lambda_{1},\dots,\lambda_{n}\sim\operatorname{Lap}_{\mathbb{Z}}(1) are i.i.d. discrete Laplacian random variables.

In particular, Lapâ„¤â¡(1)subscriptLapâ„¤1\operatorname{Lap}_{\mathbb{Z}}(1) has a bounded sub-exponential norm, therefore the proof of PropositionÂ 3.2 works for discrete Laplacian random variables as well. Consequently, CorollaryÂ 3.3 also holds for L~nâ€‹(â„±)subscript~ğ¿ğ‘›â„±\widetilde{L}_{n}(\mathcal{F}), with a different absolute constant Cğ¶C.

3.2. Privacy and Accuracy of Algorithm 1

The privacy guarantee of AlgorithmÂ 1 can be proved by checking the definition. The essence of the proof is the same as the classical Laplacian mechanism [24].

Proposition 3.4 (Privacy of AlgorithmÂ 1).

AlgorithmÂ 1 is Îµğœ€\varepsilon-differentially private.

4.2. Consistency

The true counts nÎ¸subscriptğ‘›ğœƒn_{\theta} are non-negative and consistent, i.e., the counts of subregions always add up to the count of the region:

nÎ¸â€‹0+nÎ¸â€‹1=nÎ¸for allÂ â€‹Î¸âˆˆ{0,1}â‰¤râˆ’1.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘›ğœƒ0subscriptğ‘›ğœƒ1subscriptğ‘›ğœƒfor allÂ ğœƒsuperscript01absentğ‘Ÿ1n_{\theta 0}+n_{\theta 1}=n_{\theta}\quad\text{for all }\theta\in\{0,1\}^{\leq r-1}.

The noisy counts nÎ¸â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘›â€²ğœƒn^{\prime}_{\theta} are non-negative, but not necessarily consistent. AlgorithmÂ 3 enforces consistency by adjusting the counts iteratively, from top to bottom. In the case of the deficit, when the sum of the two subregional counts is smaller than the count of the region, we increase both subregional counts. In the opposite case or surplus, we decrease both subregional counts. Apart from this requirement, we are free to distribute the deficit or surplus between the subregional counts.

It is convenient to state this requirement by considering a product partial order on â„¤+2superscriptsubscriptâ„¤2\mathbb{Z}_{+}^{2}, where we declare that (a0,a1)âª¯(b0,b1)precedes-or-equalssubscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1(a_{0},a_{1})\preceq(b_{0},b_{1}) if and only if a0â‰¤b0subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘0a_{0}\leq b_{0} and a1â‰¤b1subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘1a_{1}\leq b_{1}. We call the two vectors a,bâˆˆâ„¤2ğ‘ğ‘superscriptâ„¤2a,b\in\mathbb{Z}^{2} comparable if either aâª¯bprecedes-or-equalsğ‘ğ‘a\preceq b or bâª¯aprecedes-or-equalsğ‘ğ‘b\preceq a. Furthermore, Lâ€‹(a)ğ¿ğ‘L(a) denotes the line x+y=ağ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘x+y=a on the plane.

At each step, AlgorithmÂ 3 uses a transformation fÎ¸:â„¤+2â†’â„¤+2âˆ©Lâ€‹(mÎ¸).:subscriptğ‘“ğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptâ„¤2â†’superscriptsubscriptâ„¤2ğ¿subscriptğ‘šğœƒf_{\theta}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\mathbb{Z}_{+}^{2}\to\mathbb{Z}_{+}^{2}\cap L(m_{\theta}). It can be chosen arbitrarily; the only requirement is that fÎ¸â€‹(x)subscriptğ‘“ğœƒğ‘¥f_{\theta}(x) be comparable with xğ‘¥x. The comparability requirement is natural and non-restrictive. For example, the uniform transformation selects the closest point in the discrete interval â„¤+2âˆ©Lâ€‹(mÎ¸)superscriptsubscriptâ„¤2ğ¿subscriptğ‘šğœƒ\mathbb{Z}_{+}^{2}\cap L(m_{\theta}) in (say) the Euclidean metric. Alternatively, the proportional transformation selects the point in the discrete interval â„¤+2âˆ©Lâ€‹(mÎ¸)superscriptsubscriptâ„¤2ğ¿subscriptğ‘šğœƒ\mathbb{Z}_{+}^{2}\cap L(m_{\theta}) that is closest to the line that connects the input vector and the origin.

4.3. Synthetic data

AlgorithmÂ 3 ensures that the output counts mÎ¸subscriptğ‘šğœƒm_{\theta} are non-negative, integer, and consistent. They are also private since they are a function of the noisy counts nÎ¸â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘›â€²ğœƒn^{\prime}_{\theta}, which are private as we proved. Therefore, the counts mÎ¸subscriptğ‘šğœƒm_{\theta} can be used to generate private synthetic data by putting mÎ¸subscriptğ‘šğœƒm_{\theta} points in cell Î©Î¸subscriptÎ©ğœƒ\Omega_{\theta}. AlgorithmÂ 4 makes this formal.

4.4. Privacy and accuracy of Algorithm 4

We first prove that AlgorithmÂ 4 is differentially private. The proof idea is similar to the classic Laplacian mechanism. But now our noise is of differential scale for each level, so more delicate calculations are needed.

Theorem 4.1 (Privacy of AlgorithmÂ 4).

The vector of noisy counts (nÎ¸+Î»Î¸)subscriptğ‘›ğœƒsubscriptğœ†ğœƒ(n_{\theta}+\lambda_{\theta}) in AlgorithmÂ 4 is Îµğœ€\varepsilon-differentially private, where

4.5. Proof of TheoremÂ 4.2

For the proof of TheoremÂ 4.2, we introduce a quantitative notion for the incomparability of two vectors on the plane. For vectors a,bâˆˆâ„¤+2ğ‘ğ‘superscriptsubscriptâ„¤2a,b\in\mathbb{Z}_{+}^{2}, we define

flux(a,b):={0ifÂ aÂ andÂ bÂ are comparable,minâ¡(|a1âˆ’b1|,|a2âˆ’b2|)otherwise.\operatorname{flux}(a,b)\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}=\begin{cases}0&\text{if $a$ and $b$ are comparable,}\\ \min\left(\,\mathinner{\!\left\lvert a_{1}-b_{1}\right\rvert},\,\mathinner{\!\left\lvert a_{2}-b_{2}\right\rvert}\right)&\text{otherwise}.\end{cases}
Lemma 4.6 (Flux as incomparability).

fluxâ¡(a,b)fluxğ‘ğ‘\operatorname{flux}(a,b) is the â„“âˆsubscriptâ„“\ell_{\infty}-distance from ağ‘a to the set of points that are comparable to bğ‘b.

For example, if a=(1,9)ğ‘19a=(1,9) and b=(6,7)ğ‘67b=(6,7), then fluxâ¡(a,b)=2fluxğ‘ğ‘2\operatorname{flux}(a,b)=2. Note that ağ‘a has a distance 222 to the vector (1,7)17(1,7) which is comparable with bğ‘b.

Lemma 4.7 (Flux as transfer).

Suppose we have two bins with a1subscriptğ‘1a_{1} and a2subscriptğ‘2a_{2} balls in them. Then one can achieve b1subscriptğ‘1b_{1} and b2subscriptğ‘2b_{2} balls in these bins by:

    first making the total number of balls correct by adding a total of (b1+b2)âˆ’(a1âˆ’a2)subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2(b_{1}+b_{2})-(a_{1}-a_{2}) balls to the two bins (or removing, if that number is negative);

  2. (b)

    then transferring fluxâ¡((a1,a2),(b1,b2))fluxsubscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2\operatorname{flux}\left((a_{1},a_{2}),\,(b_{1},b_{2})\right) balls from one bin to the other.

For example, suppose that one bin has 111 ball and the other has 999. Then we can achieve 666 and 777 balls in these bins by first adding 333 balls to the first bin and transferring 222 balls from the second to the first bin. As we noted above, 222 is the flux between the vectors (1,9)19(1,9) and b=(6,7)ğ‘67b=(6,7).

A.6. Proof of Corollary 3.7

Proof.

ğ”¼â¡W1â€‹(Î¼ğ’³,Î½^)â‰¤maxiâ¡diamâ¡(Î©i)+2â€‹mÎµâ€‹nâ€‹L~mâ€‹(â„±).ğ”¼subscriptğ‘Š1subscriptğœ‡ğ’³^ğœˆsubscriptğ‘–diamsubscriptÎ©ğ‘–2ğ‘šğœ€ğ‘›subscript~ğ¿ğ‘šâ„±\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\hat{\nu})\leq\max_{i}\operatorname{diam}(\Omega_{i})+\frac{2m}{\varepsilon n}\widetilde{L}_{m}(\mathcal{F}).

When dâ‰¥3ğ‘‘3d\geq 3, the two terms are comparable. And when d=1,2ğ‘‘12d=1,2, the Laplacian complexity dominates the error. Combining the two inequalities gives the result. âˆ

A.7. Proof of TheoremÂ 4.1

Theorem 4.1 can be obtained by applying the parallel composition lemma [24]. Here we present a self-contained proof by considering an inhomogeneous version of the classical Laplacian mechanism [24].

A.14. Proof of Lemma 4.10

Proof.

Finding the 1-Wasserstein distance in the discrete case is equivalent to solving the optimal transformation problem. In fact, we can obtain Î¼Usubscriptğœ‡ğ‘ˆ\mu_{U} from Î¼Vsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘‰\mu_{V} by moving |Vâˆ–U|ğ‘‰ğ‘ˆ\mathinner{\!\left\lvert V\setminus U\right\rvert} atoms of Î¼Vsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘‰\mu_{V}, each having mass 1/|V|1ğ‘‰1/\mathinner{\!\left\lvert V\right\rvert}, and distributing their mass uniformly over Uğ‘ˆU. The distance for each movement is bounded by diamâ¡(Î©)diamÎ©\operatorname{diam}(\Omega). Therefore the 111-Wasserstein distance between Î¼Usubscriptğœ‡ğ‘ˆ\mu_{U} and Î½Vsubscriptğœˆğ‘‰\nu_{V} is bounded by |Vâˆ–U||V|â€‹diamâ¡(Î©)ğ‘‰ğ‘ˆğ‘‰diamÎ©\frac{|V\setminus U|}{|V|}\operatorname{diam}(\Omega). âˆ
